texts.definition: Effects on the game state that are negative to players regarding their position, progress, or abilities.
markups: <style="Definition">Effects on the game state that are negative to players regarding their position, progress, or abilities.</style>

Changes to game states can be good, bad, or unrelated to players' interest in the game. <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> are changes that are explicitly designed to be bad in some way to players.

Losing piece in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> is a <style="CurrentLink">Penalty</style> players suffer from the other player's attacks. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> include having to pay rent to other players but also various bad effects from "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards. Losing lives is the <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>. Players in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> can suffer <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> in the form of taking damage, becoming helpless, and dying. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pandemic">Pandemic</link></style> relate to outbreaks of diseases and possible chain reactions while in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> they consist of areas becoming impossible to use.

<style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> that relate to players' characters in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> do not only include taking damage and dying but also various disabling effects as well as potential loss of equipment, money, and experience points. Further, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can take the form of failing missions, gaining bad reputations and making enemies.

Typical reasons for receiving <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> include taking <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, triggering <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, or suffering from <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> (e.g. from <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> events). Being the target of successful <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> actions or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals also qualify. More uncommon but still possible reasons include performing specific <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> of a negative kind, e.g. failing to follow the requirements of <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> one belong to (which risks making one an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcast">Outcast</link></style>) or attacking other in what should be <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> can motivate additional <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> compared to ordinary hits, but <style="Link"><link="critical-failures">Critical Failures</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style> can be used to inflict <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> on those performing actions or attacks rather than any potential targets. Failing with the <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> (for example of accepted <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>) is another reason for receiving <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> (and the <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> are in fact what typically defines the goals as <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style>), as may be losing <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> over places or entering places controlled by others. Applying <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> to <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> can make them focus upon these goals but still let players have the choice to prioritize their efforts on other things; they are typically also applied to <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> but in this case players are forced to try and complete some actions. <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can also be added to various activities and tasks related to <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style> to emphasis and weight the importance of these different activities and tasks. The use of <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style> can let players set what <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> such exist for some goals in a game (including those outside the game system).

General categories of <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> based upon their effect include <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalties</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="revoke-rules">Revoke Rules</link></style> are another type of category based upon penalizing players for not following rules (in <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style> games typically). Besides these, there are many, more specific, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> that can be used as well. <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> (e.g. through being made a <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectator</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, and forced <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, remove <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style> from players. <style="Link"><link="turnovers">Turnovers</link></style> also do so by giving the turn in a <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Game</link></style> to some other player. <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> can make further challenges more difficult or impossible to complete but without removing all <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>. Lowering <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> can serve the same purpose. Other common ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> is to negatively modify players' <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, or to remove or destroy <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> for players, i.e. making these into <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> that are negative, e.g. spreading diseases, is rarer but another way of creating <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style>; one example of this was found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20Classic">Team Fortress Classic</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-time-manipulation">Game Time Manipulation</link></style> can be used to slow down players or speed up <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> (this is more problematic to do in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> since manipulating game time is likely to affect everyone). <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can also directly affect other goals, changing their requirements so they are harder to fulfill. <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> that do this affect a goal with <style="Link"><link="dynamic-goal-characteristics">Dynamic Goal Characteristics</link></style>.

There are several ways to modify how <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> behave. First, a basic choice is whether the <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> should be <style="Link"><link="individual-penalties">Individual Penalties</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalties</link></style> (or, similar to the latter case, affect <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Shared Resources</link></style> or linked to <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>). Second, the strength of <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can follow <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> based upon how bad a failure was, how good a success was, when in a gameplay arc players are, or some other measurable value. Regardless of the second possibility, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can be used to affect the severity of <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> and <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> can be used to modulate <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> to mitigate them somewhat (as can <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> be used to temper <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>). Letting players know how <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> are applied lets them be <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> and can let players choose to accept them for tactical reasons. <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style> can make players have to handle several different reasons for getting <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> simultaneous. One type of <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> can make players immune to <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> while another one can let players control how other players receive <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style>. Finally, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> - often bad ones - can be tied to the <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style>.

The possibility of using <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> can make any <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> avoidable even though in reality few players may be willing to engage in <style="Link"><link="save-scumming">Save Scumming</link></style> often enough to avoid all <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style>.

In <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> can be used to highlight the effects of <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> without disrupting gameplay for others.

In games where players control <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can be more emotionally experienced if the game design succeeds in making players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> with their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> are typically <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-events">Ephemeral Events</link></style> and the possibility of receiving <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> in games create <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in them. Experiencing them may break any <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> that players may have had, and can easily break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> if not following the diegesis or narration (e.g. killing a player's character but then letting them restart at earlier positions of a <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style>).

The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> and other patterns give rise to other patterns. For example, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> related to hitting or touching <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals. As another example, combined with <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style>, e.g. in the game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resistance">Resistance</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> can make players have to engage in <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. Unlike <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>,<style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> change the situation for players in ways that put challenges to <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> by requiring the ability to handle setbacks as part of what is required to master the game. This is especially try when the <style="CurrentLink">Penalties</style> remove player abilities.
